awd_titl_txt: Land Use on Privatized Pastoral Land in Kenya: The Impact of Household Strategies on Livelihoods and the Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Carolyn Lesorogol (Washington University St. Louis) along with Dr. Randall B. Boone and Dr. Michael B. Coughenour (Colorado State University) will undertake research on the relationship between individual and communal decision-making and the changing dynamics of land management in fragile ecosystems. The research will be carried out among Samburu pastoralists in Kenya.

African livestock herders depend on natural resources for their survival in difficult, semi-arid environments. Management of land historically was shared among community members but in the 1980s, some communities privatized their land, transferring decision-making from councils of elders to individual land owners. In the community studied here, new rules recently have emerged that restore a degree of communal control over individual land use decisions. Such a reassertion of community authority following privatization is unusual and provides an opportunity to investigate processes of institutional change and their impact on household decisions regarding land use as well as their broader environmental impact. 

Three questions will be addressed in the study: (1) How and why have new rules regarding individual land use decisions emerged at this time in the community? (2)To what extent and in which ways do the new rules influence household decision-making regarding land use? (3) How do household decisions on land use and livestock production aggregate and impact the overall environment and livelihood possibilities for pastoralists in this region? The study combines anthropological field research methods with computer simulation modeling of the natural environment and human decision-making. Ethnographic interviews, observations, and surveys will be used to investigate the processes of institutional innovation leading to the new grazing rules and the impact of the rules on household land use and grazing practices.  These data as well as ecological information will be used to build simulation models of the Samburu ecosystem and households. The models simulate the aggregate effects of household decisions on the environment and the feedback from the environment to household welfare. 

The importance of this research lies in the new insight it will provide into the social process through which institutions emerge and become established, with particular implication for understanding institutions for managing natural resources. The modeling component of the project will contribute to making the results more generalizable beyond this particular research context and perfecting new resarch tools that can be employed by other social scientists. The results have policy implications for governments designing land tenure and management strategies for semi-arid rangelands in Africa and elsewhere.

Livestock herding communities in Africa face challenges including semi-arid climates and droughts. They receive few government and social services and are among the poorest segments of the national population, yet these communities have been relatively successful in managing their difficult environment. In Kenya, Samburu pastoralists have experienced significant change in the rules governing land use including, in the late1980s, privatization of communally managed land in some areas. Our research used a combination of anthropological techniques (interviews, observations, and surveys) and computer simulation modeling of the physical and social environment to better understand the nature and impact of these changes on household level well-being over time.

Our findings concern two aspects of the change process. First, we investigated how people have adjusted to the new rules of private land ownership and what new land use practices and social norms have emerged  governing their use of land. Such rules and norms are important because they determine what resources people are able to access,
in turn affecting their ability to generate wealth,
produce food, and earn income. Second, using data  we collected on the
physical environment and the households in our study area, we constructed
computer simulation models linking ecological and household variables. Using these models, we simulated the effects of changes in any of the ecological or household variables on the entire system
over time. For example, we simulated the effect of decreased access to
grazing land on household livestock holdings and food availability.

Our ethnographic investigations revealed a dynamic situation in which new social norms and rules regarding how land should be used, especially how easy it is to access pasture, are still emerging. While there is consensus among the community members regarding some rules, such as fining
livestock that destroy crops (thus protecting cultivation rights), there is
less agreement on other rules, such as punishing individuals who do not allow others to graze on their private land parcels. In general, there is relatively little evidence for concerted collective action to solidify land use rules and ensure that they are enforced. Instead, we observed that many individuals are negotiating access to land that they need for livestock grazing among their neighbors. These informal negotiations vary in outcomes depending on the quality of relationships with neighbors. Unlike traditional pastoralists who are able to move away when social relations are strained, members of this community are tied to their land due to private ownership. Thus, they have incentives to find ways to come to agreement regarding resource access with neighbors; some are more effective in doing so than others. We also found that individuals have widely divergent views of the future of pastoralist livestock production in their community. Many hope to continue herding substantial numbers of livestock and feel a strong identification with a pastoralist identity while others see a future with few livestock and more emphasis on cultivation, wage labor, and other strategies. Our research suggests that a change in property rights over land has wide ranging and long term consequences not only for land use but also for social relations and cultural identity.
